caption: A lovely park like area, located in the middle of the Marais, there is plenty of seating to enjoy a baguette lunch, whilst watching the world go by in peace.

One of the most interesting things to see at Place des Vosges in the Le Marais is the equestrian statue of King Louis XIII. The original was created and erected here in 1639. However it was destroyed during the French Revolution near the end of the 18th century. A new marble statue was created by Jean-Pierre Corto and installed here in 1829.  What you will see is a depiction of the king in the manner of a Roman emperor riding through a crowd of loyal subjects. He is wearing a cloak and laurel wreath upon his head. His left hand is bent and rests near his chest while his right arm is extended. The horse appears to ride steadily forward.  It is a nice equestrian statue and worth paying a few minutes to enjoy if you plan to visit Place de Vosges and enjoy seeing monuments and statues during your travels.
Lovely park in the middle of Place des Vosges in the heart of Marais village
Nice park just out side Victor Hugos house

Emblematic square of Paris in the heart of Place des Vosges. Henri IV (1553-1610) undertook numerous works in the capital. One of his most notable achievements is this very first place Royal. It is characterized by its square shape, the symmetrical layout of the buildings whose construction, new at the time, combines stone, brick and slate. The square was inaugurated in 1615 by Louis XIII (1601-1643), on the occasion of his marriage to Anne of Austria (1601-1666). A bronze equestrian statue representing him adorned its center in 1639. The central land formerly used for a horse market became in 1682 a fenced garden shaded by lime trees. It was destroyed during the French Revolution and the equestrian statue melted. Reconstructed in the 19th century, the square combines large lawns punctuated by four fountains, works of the sculptor Jean-Pierre Cortot (1787-1843), all crowned with rows of lime and chestnut trees. A marble equestrian statue of Louis XIII, made by Cortot based on a model by Charles Dupaty (1771-1825), has been installed in its center since 1829. The square was renamed Place des Vosges in 1799, after the name of the first department to pay tax under the Revolution.
A park located in Place de Vosges, in the heart of the Marais district.

Large square park in the center of Place des Vosges, created in perfect symmetry with a fountain at each corner. In its center, a gigantic statue of Louis XIII, almost lost in the trees, overlooks this garden whose design blends well with the shape of the place. At the end of July, it was sunny and there were a lot of people in the shade. I like this park surrounded by these old buildings full of character.

One of the oldest squares in Paris (16th century), this square has one of the most expensive real estate, and, by the way, Dominique Strauss Kahn lives there (a failed candidate for the presidency of France). And the writer Victor Hugo once lived there, in whose apartment we visited. I must say, he didn’t live badly, he lived richly! The museum is quiet, cozy, interesting...
Great park! I often go there to have lunch on the grass :)
A historic square park. There are plenty of benches, and of course you can sit on the grass. Right next to the Victor Hugo Memorial.

One of the majestic settings of the capital, the name of Square Louis XIII is the reason that in the center there is an equestrian statue of the King of France. It is pleasant to relax on the lawn and to hear the sound of the fountains in summer. For children aged 3 to 12 years old, it is sad that it is not secured by a specific fence like the sandboxes. There are water points and Wi-Fi.

Very large square, square, of the Place des Vosges which undoubtedly takes its name from the large statue of Louis XIII (13) which is located in the middle of the park... At each corner is a fountain with lawns around it where onlookers gather to picnic or chat, no doubt, about big existential questions... A children's play area is located in the corner opposite Victor Hugo's house.... Attendance is still very high, mainly by families who live in this privileged area of ​​Paris...!
Don't be fooled by the opening time indicated on the gates - 7am ​​- the park doesn't open until 8am.
Fantastic and fascinating as always. Very busy on Saturday afternoons
Magnificent square in the heart of Place des Vosges with a children's play area.
Large and can accommodate many people. A quiet place near the Place de Bastille.
Curious century-old mansion, very well maintained.
Beautiful statue perfectly in its place in the center of the superb Place des Vosges!
Stunning fountain with lovely areas to play
An absolutely magnificent statue! It gives character to the place.
